elements.content: Five new metal complexes, [Zn3(L1)2(BTC)2]·6H2O (1), [Zn3(L1)(BTC)2] (2), [Cd3(L1)(BTC)2] (3), [Cd3(L2)(BTC)2]·4H2O (4), and [Cd3(L2)(BTC)2(H2O)2] (5), have been successfully synthesized by solvothermal reactions of corresponding metal salts with 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) and imidazole-containing ligands 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (L1) and 3,3′,5,5′-tetra(imidazol-1-yl)-1,1′-biphenyl (L2). The structures of the complexes were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Complexes 1 and 2 obtained at different reaction temperatures show different structures: 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) net with Zn-BTC3– layers pillared by L1 ligands, while 2 has a 3D structure with a Zn-BTC3– framework and Zn-L1 chain. Complexes 2 and 3, which contain different metal centers, have similar framework structures but different coordination modes of carboxylate groups. 4 and 5 that were prepared from different solvents show different 3D structures. The thermal stability, photoluminescence, and sorption properties of the complexes were investigated.

The thermal stability, photoluminescence, and sorption properties of the complexes were investigated.

elements.content: Five new zinc(II)/cadmium(II) complexes constructed by mixed 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) and imidazole-containing ligands show diverse structures driven by different reaction temperatures, ligands, and reaction solvents. The N2/H2O adsorption properties of 1 and 4 were explored.

elements.content: The past decade has witnessed the rapid development of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) to which great efforts have been devoted not only owing to their intriguing structural architectures and novel topologies but also because of their potential applications in catalysis, gas/solvent storage and separation, luminescence, etc. However, control-synthesizing MOFs and predicting their structures remain challenging. The self-assembly of MOFs is dominated by predesigned organic linkers, metal centers, reaction solvent, pH value, temperature, metal-to-ligand ratio, etc., and understanding the role of the above factors in self-assembly process is important for synthesizing target materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The past decade has witnessed the rapid development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to which great efforts have been devoted not only owing to their intriguing structural architectures and novel topologies but also because of their potential applications in catalysis, gas/solvent storage and separation, luminescence, etc. However, control-synthesizing MOFs and predicting their structures remain challenging. The self-assembly of MOFs is dominated by predesigned organic linkers, metal centers, reaction solvent, pH value, temperature, metal-to-ligand ratio, etc., and understanding the role of the above factors in self-assembly process is important for synthesizing target materials.

elements.content: On the other hand, proper organic bridging linkers are critical in constructing coordination polymers. 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), which has advantages due to its rigid multicarboxylic groups, may act as bridging ligands with various coordination modes after being deprotonated. In our previous studies, a flexible tridentate ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene managed to construct MOFs with different structures and properties. Because of its flexibility, it is apt to display variable coordination modes resulting from the geometry restrictions and the facilely twisted conformations, thus leading to diverse structures such as cages, honeycombs, interpenetrating networks, and helical structures. Thus, it is a powerful candidate for constructing coordination polymers with novel structures and topologies together with H3BTC. Given that the flexibility of the ligand significantly affects the structure of resultant coordination polymers, a rigid tetradentate ligand 3,3′,5,5′-tetra(imidazol-1-yl)-1,1′-biphenyl is introduced to form new complexes with unique structures and topologies. In this work, H3BTC as well as 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (L1) and 3,3′,5,5′-tetra(imidazol-1-yl)-1,1′-biphenyl (L2) were used to react with Zn(II)/Cd(II) salts to fabricate five new coordination polymers, i.e., [Zn3(L1)2(BTC)2]·6H2O (1), [Zn3(L1)(BTC)2] (2), [Cd3(L1)(BTC)2] (3), [Cd3(L2)(BTC)2]·4H2O (4), and [Cd3(L2)(BTC)2(H2O)2] (5). On the basis of identical reactants, the structures of complexes 1 and 2 differed in the case of altered reaction temperatures. Meanwhile, 4 and 5 were obtained by changing the reaction solvents.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Ligands L1 and L2 were synthesized according to reported procedures. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer at the Modern Analysis Center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. The luminescence spectra for powdered solid samples were measured on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. The pass width in the measurements of emission and excitation spectra was set at 5 nm, and all the measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions. Sorption experiments were carried out on a Belsorp-max volumetric gas sorption instrument. The bulk dehydrated samples of 1 and 4 for sorption experiments were obtained by heating the fresh complexes at 160 and 190 °C, respectively, for 10 h under high vacuum to remove free water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Ligands L1 and L2 were synthesized according to reported procedures. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer at the Modern Analysis Center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. The luminescence spectra for powdered solid samples were measured on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. The pass width in the measurements of emission and excitation spectra was set at 5 nm, and all the measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions. Sorption experiments were carried out on a Belsorp-max volumetric gas sorption instrument. The bulk dehydrated samples of 1 and 4 for sorption experiments were obtained by heating the fresh complexes at 160 and 190 °C, respectively, for 10 h under high vacuum to remove free water molecules.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (14.9 mg, 0.05 mmol), H3BTC (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), L1 (9.6 mg, 0.03 mmol), MeOH (3 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was adjusted to pH ≈ 7 using a 0.5 mol L–1 NaOH solution. The mixture was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. After being cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals of 1 were acquired in 45% yield. Anal. Calcd for C54H54N12O18Zn3: C 47.86, H 4.02, N 12.40%. Found: C 47.78, H 3.99, N 12.34%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3400 (m), 3110 (w), 1557 (m), 1514 (s), 1494 (w), 1431 (s), 1382 (s), 1307 (m), 1149 (s), 1048(m), 979(w), 841 (s), 736 (m), 724 (s), 645 (w), 538 (m).

elements.content: X-ray diffraction measurements for 3 were made on a Rigaku Rapid II imaging plate area detector with Mo Kα radiation (0.71075 Å) using MicroMax-007HF microfocus rotating anode X-ray generator and VariMax-Mo optics at 200 K. The structure of 3 was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and expanded using Fourier techniques with DIRFID-99. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2 . The hydrogen atoms in 3 were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. All calculations for 3, except for refinement (SHELXL-97), were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. The crystallographic data of 1, 2, 4, and 5 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms of free water molecules in 1 and 4 were not found, while those of coordinated water molecules in 5 were found directly, and all the hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements of the complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

The structure of 3 was solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and expanded using Fourier techniques with DIRFID-99. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least-squares method on F  2 . The hydrogen atoms in 3 were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. All calculations for 3, except for refinement (SHELXL-97), were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. The crystallographic data of 1, 2, 4, and 5 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms of free water molecules in 1 and 4 were not found, while those of coordinated water molecules in 5 were found directly, and all the hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements of the complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two Zn(II) atoms, one of which sits on a special position with half occupancy, one L1, one BTC3–, and three free water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is coordinated by two O atoms from two different BTC3‑ and two N ones from two distinct L1 ligands to give rise to a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each BTC3– ligand in 1 connects three metal atoms using its three carboxylate groups each with the μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme a). A honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) network is formed by BTC3– ligands and Zn(II) atoms (Figure b) by ignoring the connection with L1 pillared by which eventually generates the three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 (Figure c). The free water molecules occupy the cavities of the net and interact with the framework via C–H···O hydrogen bonds. The void volume in 1 is 522.5 Å3, which is 9.5% per unit cell as calculated by PLATON.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn3(L1)2(BTC)2]⋅6H2O (1)

The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two Zn(II) atoms, one of which sits on a special position with half occupancy, one L1, one BTC3-, and three free water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is coordinated by two O atoms from two different BTC3-  and two N ones from two distinct L1 ligands to give rise to a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each BTC3- ligand in 1 connects three metal atoms using its three carboxylate groups each with the μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme a). A honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) network is formed by BTC3- ligands and Zn(II) atoms (Figure b) by ignoring the connection with L1 pillared by which eventually generates the three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 (Figure c). The free water molecules occupy the cavities of the net and interact with the framework via C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. The void volume in 1 is 522.5 Å3, which is 9.5% per unit cell as calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: Given other experimental conditions for synthesizing 1 unchanged, a differently structured complex 2 was prepared at 210 °C to investigate the effect of reaction temperature on structure. As depicted in Figure a, Zn1 atom is surrounded by five O atoms of carboxylate groups provided by five different BTC3– ligands to give a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. Zn2 atom is four-coordinated by two N atoms (N12, N52F) from two different L1 and two O ones (O3, O7D) from two distinct BTC3– ligands, and the Zn3 atom is five-coordinated by four O atoms from three different BTC3– and one N atom (N32E) from one L1 ligand. It is noteworthy that there are Zn2(OCO)2 and Zn2(OCO)4 paddle-wheel subunits comprising two Zn3 and two Zn1 atoms (Figure a), respectively.

Crystal Structure of [Zn3(L1)(BTC)2] (2)

Given other experimental conditions for synthesizing 1 unchanged, a differently structured complex 2 was prepared at 210 °C to investigate the effect of reaction temperature on structure. As depicted in Figure a, Zn1 atom is surrounded by five O atoms of carboxylate groups provided by five different BTC3- ligands to give a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. Zn2 atom is four-coordinated by two N atoms (N12, N52F) from two different L1 and two O ones (O3, O7D) from two distinct BTC3- ligands, and the Zn3 atom is five-coordinated by four O atoms from three different BTC3- and one N atom (N32E) from one L1 ligand. It is noteworthy that there are Zn2(OCO)2 and Zn2(OCO)4 paddle-wheel subunits comprising two Zn3 and two Zn1 atoms (Figure a), respectively.

elements.content: In complex 2, two BTC3– ligands present different coordination modes as illustrated in Scheme b,c, and each BTC3– adopts a μ5-bridging mode to connect five Zn(II), in which the carboxylate groups show μ2-η1:η1, μ1-η1:η0-monodentate, and μ1-η1:η1-chelating fashions. The BTC3– ligands connect Zn(II) atoms to form a 3D framework (Figure b). In addition, L1 with cis-, trans-, trans-conformation (Scheme a) binds three Zn(II) atoms and fills the 3D structure of Zn-BTC3–, leading to the final structure of 2 (Figure c).

The BTC3- ligands connect Zn(II) atoms to form a 3D framework (Figure b). In addition, L1 with cis-, trans-, trans-conformation (Scheme a) binds three Zn(II) atoms and fills the 3D structure of Zn-BTC3-, leading to the final structure of 2 (Figure c).

elements.content: When Cd(NO3)2·4H2O instead of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was used in the reaction, complex 3 was acquired. The single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 3 and 2 crystallize in the same space group and have similar cell parameters (Table ), indicating that they have similar structures. There are also Cd2(OCO)2 and Cd2(OCO)4 subunits in 3 (Figure a). However, compared with the Zn(II) atoms of five-, four-, and five-coordination with O5 (Zn1), N2O2 (Zn2), and N1O4 (Zn3) donor sets in 2 (Figure a), the three Cd(II) atoms in 3 are six-, five-, and five-coordinated by N2O4 (Cd1), N1O4 (Cd2), and O5 (Cd3), respectively (Figure a). On the other hand, the BTC3– ligands in 3 present two different coordination modes as shown in Scheme c,d. The mode 1d BTC3– ligand connects six Cd(II) atoms by adopting the μ6-bridging mode. One of the three carboxylates is in μ2-η1:η2-chelating/bridging, and the other two are in μ2-η1:η1 fashion. Ignoring the connection with L1, BTC3– ligands produce a 3D framework by linking Cd(II) atoms (Figure b). L1 adopts an identical conformation to that in 2 and yields the final structure of 3 by linking the 3D structure of Cd-BTC3– (Figure c).

Crystal Structure of [Cd3(L1)(BTC)2] (3)

When Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O instead of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was used in the reaction, complex 3 was acquired. The single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 3 and 2 crystallize in the same space group and have similar cell parameters (Table ), indicating that they have similar structures. There are also Cd2(OCO)2 and Cd2(OCO)4 subunits in 3 (Figure a). However, compared with the Zn(II) atoms of five-, four-, and five-coordination with O5 (Zn1), N2O2 (Zn2), and N1O4 (Zn3) donor sets in 2 (Figure a), the three Cd(II) atoms in 3 are six-, five-, and five-coordinated by N2O4 (Cd1), N1O4 (Cd2), and O5 (Cd3), respectively (Figure a). On the other hand, the BTC3- ligands in 3 present two different coordination modes as shown in Scheme c,d. The mode 1d BTC3- ligand connects six Cd(II) atoms by adopting the μ6-bridging mode. One of the three carboxylates is in μ2-η1:η2-chelating/bridging, and the other two are in μ2-η1:η1 fashion. Ignoring the connection with L1, BTC3- ligands produce a 3D framework by linking Cd(II) atoms (Figure b). L1 adopts an identical conformation to that in 2 and yields the final structure of 3 by linking the 3D structure of Cd-BTC3- (Figure c).

elements.content: Considering the influence of ligand flexibility on complex structure, complex 4, with a different structure, was synthesized by replacing the flexible tridentate L1 with a rigid tetradentate ligand L2 (Scheme ). As shown in Figure a, three six-coordinated Cd(II) atoms are located at special positions with half occupancy. Both Cd1 and Cd2 are coordinated by two N atoms from two L2 and four O ones from two BTC3–, while Cd3 is surrounded by six O atoms from four distinct BTC3– ligands. In addition, Cd2 and Cd3 compose a binuclear subunit via O bridges. The BTC3– ligand in 4 shows a different coordination mode (Scheme e) from those in 1–3. In 4, two of the three carboxylate groups of BTC3– adopt chelating fashion, and the third one adopts a μ2-η1:η2-chelating/bridging mode; thus it can be regarded as a μ4-bridging ligand. If the connections through the carboxylate groups of BTC3– are ignored, the imidazole groups of L2 connect Cd(II) atoms to bring about a 2D network (Figure b). Then the adjacent layers are further linked by BTC3– ligands, thereby resulting in the final 3D framework of 4 (Figure c).

Crystal Structure of [Cd3(L2)(BTC)2]⋅4H2O (4)

Considering the influence of ligand flexibility on complex structure, complex 4, with a different structure, was synthesized by replacing the flexible tridentate L1 with a rigid tetradentate ligand L2 (Scheme ). As shown in Figure a, three six-coordinated Cd(II) atoms are located at special positions with half occupancy. Both Cd1 and Cd2 are coordinated by two N atoms from two L2 and four O ones from two BTC3-, while Cd3 is surrounded by six O atoms from four distinct BTC3- ligands. In addition, Cd2 and Cd3 compose a binuclear subunit via O bridges. The BTC3- ligand in 4 shows a different coordination mode (Scheme e) from those in 1-3. In 4, two of the three carboxylate groups of BTC3- adopt chelating fashion, and the third one adopts a μ2-η1:η2-chelating/bridging mode; thus it can be regarded as a μ4-bridging ligand. If the connections through the carboxylate groups of BTC3- are ignored, the imidazole groups of L2 connect Cd(II) atoms to bring about a 2D network (Figure b). Then the adjacent layers are further linked by BTC3- ligands, thereby resulting in the final 3D framework of 4 (Figure c).

elements.content: Complex 5 was obtained in mixed CH3CN/H2O rather than MeOH/H2O for preparing 4. The Cd1 atom sitting on the specific position with half occupancy is coordinated by six O atoms from four distinct BTC3– ligands, while the Cd2 atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two different L2, four O ones from two different BTC3– ligands, and one H2O molecule (Figure a). Meanwhile, one Cd1 and two Cd2 atoms form a trinuclear Cd3(OCO)2 subunit through the bridge of carboxylate groups. In 5, two of the three carboxylate groups of BTC3– adopt chelating fashion, and the third one adopts μ2-η1:η1-bridging mode (Scheme f); thus it can be regarded as a μ4-bridging ligand. If the connections of Cd1–O3 and Cd1–O4 are ignored, L2 and the rest of BTC3– link the Cd(II) atoms to form a 2D network (Figure b). Thereafter the adjoining layers are further connected by Cd–O interactions, thus forming the final 3D framework of 5 (Figure c).

Crystal Structure of [Cd3(L2)(BTC)2(H2O)2] (5)

Complex 5 was obtained in mixed CH3CN/H2O rather than MeOH/H2O for preparing 4. The Cd1 atom sitting on the specific position with half occupancy is coordinated by six O atoms from four distinct BTC3- ligands, while the Cd2 atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two different L2, four O ones from two different BTC3- ligands, and one H2O molecule (Figure a). Meanwhile, one Cd1 and two Cd2 atoms form a trinuclear Cd3(OCO)2 subunit through the bridge of carboxylate groups. In 5, two of the three carboxylate groups of BTC3- adopt chelating fashion, and the third one adopts μ2-η1:η1-bridging mode (Scheme f); thus it can be regarded as a μ4-bridging ligand. If the connections of Cd1-O3 and Cd1-O4 are ignored, L2 and the rest of BTC3- link the Cd(II) atoms to form a 2D network (Figure b). Thereafter the adjoining layers are further connected by Cd-O interactions, thus forming the final 3D framework of 5 (Figure c).

elements.content: BTC3– in 1–5 stemmed from the complete deprotonation of H3BTC is consistent with IR spectral data that lack vibration bands between 1680 and 1760 cm–1 corresponding to −COOH (see ). In the meantime, BTC3– presents six coordination modes as illustrated in Scheme . The results further indicate that BTC3– is versatile in construction of MOFs and thus renders the structural predictions of the resulting complexes rather difficult simultaneously.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison the Structures of Complexes 1-5 

BTC3- in 1-5 stemmed from the complete deprotonation of H3BTC is consistent with IR spectral data that lack vibration bands between 1680 and 1760 cm-1 corresponding to -COOH (see ). In the meantime, BTC3- presents six coordination modes as illustrated in Scheme . The results further indicate that BTC3- is versatile in construction of MOFs and thus renders the structural predictions of the resulting complexes rather difficult simultaneously.

elements.content: Differently structured 1 and 2, prepared under same reaction conditions except for the temperatures from 180 to 210 °C, suggest that reaction temperature evidently influences their structures. Regardless of different metal centers, complex 3 has similar binuclear subunits and a framework structure to those of 2. However, the two kinds of BTC3– ligands in 3 act as 3- and 5-connected nodes, whereas those in 2 are 3- and 4-connected nodes. Moreover, L1 and L2 intrinsically impact the frameworks of the complexes remarkably, thus varying the structures of 3 and 4. The different structures of 4 and 5 indicate that reaction solvent also has impact on the assembly of complexes. The results herein further confirm that the metal center, flexibility and coordination number of the imidazole-containing ligand, varied coordination modes of the BTC3– ligand, reaction temperature, and solvent exert a subtle but crucial influence on the structures of the complexes.

elements.content:
The pure phases of complexes 1–5 were confirmed by PXRD measurements, and the results are shown in . Meanwhile, each PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized sample is consistent with the simulated one.

The thermal stabilities of 1–5 were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and the results are shown in . Complex 1 experiences a weight loss of 7.78% between ca. 50–140 °C, which corresponds to the liberation of free water molecules (calcd 7.96%). Complexes 2 and 3 did not show obvious weight losses before the decomposition of frameworks at about 320 and 400 °C, respectively, which are in agreement with the results of crystal structures. 4 and 5 undergo weight losses of 5.43% and 2.67%, respectively, which can be assigned to the losses of free and coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.79% for 4 and 2.98% for 5), and the frameworks of 4 and 5 remain stable up to approximately 400 °C.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, Thermal Stability, and Photoluminescence Properties of the Complexes

The pure phases of complexes 1-5 were confirmed by PXRD measurements, and the results are shown in . Meanwhile, each PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized sample is consistent with the simulated one.

The thermal stabilities of 1-5 were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and the results are shown in . Complex 1 experiences a weight loss of 7.78% between ca. 50-140 °C, which corresponds to the liberation of free water molecules (calcd 7.96%). Complexes 2 and 3 did not show obvious weight losses before the decomposition of frameworks at about 320 and 400 °C, respectively, which are in agreement with the results of crystal structures. 4 and 5 undergo weight losses of 5.43% and 2.67%, respectively, which can be assigned to the losses of free and coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.79% for 4 and 2.98% for 5), and the frameworks of 4 and 5 remain stable up to approximately 400 °C.

elements.content: Metal complexes consisting of d10 metal atoms and organic ligands are promising candidates for applicable hybrid photoactive materials such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The solid-state luminescent emission spectra of 1–5 under the same experimental conditions were measured and exhibited in Figure , and those of L1, L2 and free H3BTC ligands are given in . Emission bands were observed at 392 nm (λex = 353 nm) for 1, 415 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 2, 410 nm (λex = 357 nm) for 3, 428 nm (λex = 370 nm) for 4, and 421 nm (λex = 340 nm) for 5. The photoluminescence emissions of the complexes are ascribed to the intraligand transition of the ligand since H3BTC, L1, and L2 emitted similarly at 398 nm (λex = 337 nm), 383 nm (λex = 342 nm), and 429 nm (λex = 360 nm), respectively. The red- or blue-shift of the emission maximum between the complex and the ligand may originate from the coordination of the ligand to metal centers.

elements.content: Given the cavities of the frameworks in 1 and 4 in which are filled with noncoordinated water molecules, further TGA and PXRD measurements were carried out to ascertain the stability of the frameworks. Sorption Property

Given the cavities of the frameworks in 1 and 4 in which are filled with noncoordinated water molecules, further TGA and PXRD measurements were carried out to ascertain the stability of the frameworks. The TGA curves of the dehydrated samples of 1' and 4' indicate that the water molecules in fresh 1 and 4 can be removed completely by being heated at 160 and 190 °C for 10 h under high vacuum, and the dehydrated frameworks of 1' and 4' remain stable up to 340 and 360 °C, respectively (). The PXRD patterns of 1' and 4' exhibit changes in peak position and intensity especially at high angles, suggesting the structural transformation after removing the water molecules. Fortunately, the PXRD patterns of the rehydrated samples match well with those of the as-synthesized ones (), indicating the dynamic nature of the frameworks, and thus sorption measurements were carried out.

elements.content: Five new coordination polymers with diverse structures were successfully constructed from H3BTC and flexible/rigid imidazole-containing ligands with Zn(II)/Cd(II) metal salts by the solvothermal method. The results show that the structural diversification of the complexes may be attributed to altered reaction temperature and solvent as well as the coordination mode of the ligands. Meanwhile, this work suggests that it is feasible to construct MOFs with novel structures and topologies by combining multidentate imidazole-containing ligands and multicarboxylates with suitable metal centers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Five new coordination polymers with diverse structures were successfully constructed from H3BTC and flexible/rigid imidazole-containing ligands with Zn(II)/Cd(II) metal salts by the solvothermal method. The results show that the structural diversification of the complexes may be attributed to altered reaction temperature and solvent as well as the coordination mode of the ligands. Meanwhile, this work suggests that it is feasible to construct MOFs with novel structures and topologies by combining multidentate imidazole-containing ligands and multicarboxylates with suitable metal centers.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (14.9 mg, 0.05 mmol), H3BTC (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), L1 (9.6 mg, 0.03 mmol), MeOH (3 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was adjusted to pH ≈ 7 using a 0.5 mol L–1 NaOH solution. The mixture was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. After being cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals of 1 were acquired in 45% yield. Anal. Calcd for C54H54N12O18Zn3: C 47.86, H 4.02, N 12.40%. Found: C 47.78, H 3.99, N 12.34%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3400 (m), 3110 (w), 1557 (m), 1514 (s), 1494 (w), 1431 (s), 1382 (s), 1307 (m), 1149 (s), 1048(m), 979(w), 841 (s), 736 (m), 724 (s), 645 (w), 538 (m).

Preparation of [Zn<sub>3</sub>(L1)(BTC)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 was prepared by the same method as that of 1 except that the reaction temperature was changed from 180 to 210 °C. After being cooled to room temperature, yellow prism crystals were obtained in 68% yield. Anal. Calcd for C36H24N6O12Zn3: C 46.56, H 2.60, N 9.05%. Found: C 46.49, H 2.55, N 9.01%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1626 (s), 1571 (m), 1525 (w), 1438 (m), 1336 (s), 1231 (m), 1094 (m), 1030 (w), 956 (m), 849 (w), 770 (w), 732 (s), 656 (m), 632 (w).

Preparation of [Cd<sub>3</sub>(L1)(BTC)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

The complex was synthesized by the same procedure used for preparing 1 except that Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (15.4 mg, 0.05 mmol), instead of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (14.9 mg, 0.05 mmol), was used as the starting material. After being cooled to room temperature, colorless platelet crystals were obtained in 40% yield. Anal. Calcd for C36H24N6O12Cd3: C 40.42; H, 2.26; N, 7.86%. Found: C, 40.30; H, 2.20; N, 7.83%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1634 (s), 1616 (s), 1580 (m), 1535 (s), 1438 (s), 1359 (s), 1234 (w), 1109 (m), 1086 (m), 941 (w), 847 (w), 765 (m), 729 (s), 656 (m).

Preparation of [Cd<sub>3</sub>(L2)(BTC)<sub>2</sub>]·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Complex 4 was fabricated by the same procedure used for the preparation of 3 except that imidazole-containing ligand L1 was replaced with L2 (10.5 mg, 0.025 mmol). Yellow pellet crystals of 4 were obtained in 65% yield. Anal. Calcd for C42H32N8O16Cd3: C, 40.62; H, 2.60; N, 9.02%. Found: C, 40.48; H, 2.49; N, 8.96%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3420 (m), 3144 (w), 1611 (s), 1544 (s), 1501 (m), 1438 (s), 1371 (s), 1252 (m), 1114 (w), 1066 (m), 1009 (w), 961 (w), 867 (w), 765 (m), 736 (s), 681 (w).

Preparation of [Cd<sub>3</sub>(L2)(BTC)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

Complex 5 was prepared by the same procedure used for the preparation of 4 except that CH3CN (2 mL) and H2O (6 mL) were used as solvents. After being cooled to room temperature, yellow block crystals were obtained in 35% yield. Anal. Calcd for C42H28N8O14Cd3: C 41.83, H 2.34, N 9.29%. Found: C 41.69, H 2.28, N 9.21%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3400 (m), 3133 (w),1612 (s), 1535 (s), 1505 (m), 1434 (m), 1368 (s), 1243 (w), 1112 (w), 1070 (m), 1017 (w), 927 (w), 857 (w), 767 (m), 722 (m), 649 (w).

cln_elements.content:
The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two Zn(II) atoms, one of which sits on a special position with half occupancy, one L1, one BTC3–, and three free water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is coordinated by two O atoms from two different BTC3‑ and two N ones from two distinct L1 ligands to give rise to a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each BTC3– ligand in 1 connects three metal atoms using its three carboxylate groups each with the μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme a). A honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) network is formed by BTC3– ligands and Zn(II) atoms (Figure b) by ignoring the connection with L1 pillared by which eventually generates the three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 (Figure c). The free water molecules occupy the cavities of the net and interact with the framework via C–H···O hydrogen bonds. The void volume in 1 is 522.5 Å3, which is 9.5% per unit cell as calculated by PLATON.

PXRD, Thermal Stability, and Photoluminescence Properties of the Complexes

The pure phases of complexes 1–5 were confirmed by PXRD measurements, and the results are shown in . Meanwhile, each PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized sample is consistent with the simulated one.

The thermal stabilities of 1–5 were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and the results are shown in . Complex 1 experiences a weight loss of 7.78% between ca. 50–140 °C, which corresponds to the liberation of free water molecules (calcd 7.96%). Complexes 2 and 3 did not show obvious weight losses before the decomposition of frameworks at about 320 and 400 °C, respectively, which are in agreement with the results of crystal structures. 4 and 5 undergo weight losses of 5.43% and 2.67%, respectively, which can be assigned to the losses of free and coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.79% for 4 and 2.98% for 5), and the frameworks of 4 and 5 remain stable up to approximately 400 °C.

Metal complexes consisting of d10 metal atoms and organic ligands are promising candidates for applicable hybrid photoactive materials such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The solid-state luminescent emission spectra of 1–5 under the same experimental conditions were measured and exhibited in Figure , and those of L1, L2 and free H3BTC ligands are given in . Emission bands were observed at 392 nm (λex = 353 nm) for 1, 415 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 2, 410 nm (λex = 357 nm) for 3, 428 nm (λex = 370 nm) for 4, and 421 nm (λex = 340 nm) for 5. The photoluminescence emissions of the complexes are ascribed to the intraligand transition of the ligand since H3BTC, L1, and L2 emitted similarly at 398 nm (λex = 337 nm), 383 nm (λex = 342 nm), and 429 nm (λex = 360 nm), respectively. The red- or blue-shift of the emission maximum between the complex and the ligand may originate from the coordination of the ligand to metal centers.

Sorption Property

Given the cavities of the frameworks in 1 and 4 in which are filled with noncoordinated water molecules, further TGA and PXRD measurements were carried out to ascertain the stability of the frameworks. The TGA curves of the dehydrated samples of 1′ and 4′ indicate that the water molecules in fresh 1 and 4 can be removed completely by being heated at 160 and 190 °C for 10 h under high vacuum, and the dehydrated frameworks of 1′ and 4′ remain stable up to 340 and 360 °C, respectively (). The PXRD patterns of 1′ and 4′ exhibit changes in peak position and intensity especially at high angles, suggesting the structural transformation after removing the water molecules. Fortunately, the PXRD patterns of the rehydrated samples match well with those of the as-synthesized ones (), indicating the dynamic nature of the frameworks, and thus sorption measurements were carried out.

The adsorption properties of N2 at 77 K and H2O at 298 K were examined and shown in Figure . The sorption curves of 1′ and 4′ indicate N2 surface adsorption other than uptake at 77 K. Nevertheless, H2O vapor adsorption of 1′ and 4′ was discerned. The final values of 109.28 cm3 g–1 (87.86 mg g–1) for 1′ and 71.85 cm3 g–1 (57.76 mg g–1) for 4′ at P = 0.99 atm correspond to 6.05 and 3.8 H2O molecules per formula unit for 1 and 4, respectively, which resemble the results of crystallographic analysis (1: 6 H2O molecules; 4: 4 H2O molecules). The large hysteresis and incomplete desorption imply strong adsorbate–adsorbent interactions.

A honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) network is formed by BTC3- ligands and Zn(II) atoms (Figure b) by ignoring the connection with L1 pillared by which eventually generates the three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 (Figure c). The free water molecules occupy the cavities of the net and interact with the framework via C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. The void volume in 1 is 522.5 Å3, which is 9.5% per unit cell as calculated by PLATON.
